title: HTML Cross-Browser Compatibility
subject: HTML
theory:
# Cross-Browser Compatibility

Not all browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge) work exactly the same way. HTML/CSS code can look different on different browsers.

## 1. Browser Engines
*   **Blink:** Chrome, Edge, Opera, Brave.
*   **Webkit:** Safari (iOS).
*   **Gecko:** Firefox.

Most differences are minor today, but some HTML5 features might not be supported in older versions.

## 2. CSS Reset / Normalize.css
Every browser has its own default styles (User Agent Stylesheet). E.g., Firefox might use 10px margin for `body`, Chrome uses 8px.
*   **Solution:** Use a CSS Reset (removes all styles) or Normalize.css (makes them consistent) at the start of your CSS.

## 3. Polyfills
A **polyfill** is a piece of JavaScript code that provides modern functionality on older browsers that do not natively support it.

## 4. Validating Support
Use **CanIUse.com** to check if a feature (like `<dialog>` or WebP) is supported by the browsers you target.

<!-- Conditional Comment (Old IE) -->
<!--[if lt IE 9]>
  <script src="html5shiv.js"></script>
<![endif]-->
examples.explanation: Historic method to support HTML5 tags in IE.

common_mistakes.correction: Just because it works on your laptop doesn't meant it works on an iPhone (Safari). Always test on multiple browsers.
Mobile browsers behave differently (touch events, viewport).

interview_questions.question: What is a polyfill?
interview_questions.answer: Code (usually JS) that implements a feature on web browsers that do not support the feature essentially 'filling' the gap.

interview_questions.question: What is Normalize.css?
interview_questions.answer: A CSS file that renders all elements more consistently and in line with modern standards. It targets only the styles that need normalizing, unlike a Reset which strips everything.

practice_problems.problem: Check if 'IntersectionObserver' is supported in IE11.

real_world_use_cases.description: Sites that must support everyone often have strict requirements to support older browsers like IE11, heavily relying on polyfills.

summary: The web is fragmented. Different browsers use different engines. While standards have improved, ensuring your site looks and functions effectively across Chrome, Safari, Firefox, and legacy browsers requires tools like Normalize.css and Polyfills.
